chunks.original_text: 司马在庭东向诵生神章者，即长生法师大司马也。 姓栢成，名欻生，乃上清真人也。 男则敬诺而唱恭，女则敬顺而唱奉，则分贵贱也。 如诗中弄璋瓦之异。 已上莫非一身之神，才候气满，则百神并集。 然神以气为母，神乃气之子，神能住气，气能留形，则长生久视，又何难哉。 惜乎人不晓此，以欲灭命，以利轻生，深可叹哉。 夫人得还，生於人道，濯形太阳，惊天骇地，贵亦难胜。 天真地神三界齐临，亦不轻也。 当生之时，亦不为陋也。 所以能爱其形，保其神，贵其气，固其根，终不死坏而得神仙，骨肉同飞，上登三清，是与三气合德，九气齐并也。 但人得生而自不能尊其气，贵其形，保其命，爱其神，自取死坏，离其本真耳。 《混元迷禀》曰：人生天地之间，禀二气之和，冠万物之首，居最灵之地，总五行之秀。 参於三才，与天地并，可谓至贵无伦矣。 傥得人身，当自保爱，盖生死界畔迷谬甚多矣。 人身者，如立板走丸，得人身者，如沂流上船，此神王所以区区愍众生不自觉知，轻生徇死，不贵人身而发为此问也。 才得人身，叉须诣南丹火炼池中，涤以黄华之水，然后投胎就舍，方始成人。 今此经乃谓之濯形太阳而不谓之黄华者，何耶。 盖黄华者，阳之精，在日之上馆，一名洞阳宫。 中有流火之池，中有黄华之水。 彼问神人常以此水灌濯形容，故吾教荐亡，有长生简符，指此也。 自从为人经许多节次，诚所谓惊天骇地，三界齐临，不为陋也。 每每诵至此篇，掩卷太息，盖此身与天地并，气与阴阳通，此身乃三宝之身，此气乃阴阳之气，尊莫过於三宝，神莫大於阴阳，动其机万物化宜乎。 惊天骇地，三界齐临，不为过也。 既得此生，不胜庆幸，岂可忽诸。 但人不自爱形保神，贵气固根，与三气合德，九气齐并者，切缘私心胜而智慧少，每以隋侯之珠弹千仞之雀者，比比皆是，安得不离其本真乎。 九天生神章，乃三洞飞玄之气，三合成音，结成灵文，混合百神，隐韵内名，生气结形，自然之章。 天地之大，非气不运。 人之一身，非气不立。 三洞宝经，非气不结。 谓之自然之章者，非从人说也。 谨按太真十二科，以自然本文为初，寔先天之教也。 九天丈人告三天玉童曰：元丹胎精中记，乃生玄之初，结太空自然之气，以成宝文，今生神章是也。 飞玄者，以三气之中，玄气为终，其气如云，飞徊於太空之中，三合而后成音。 三合者，《本始经》云：夫人形体为一，身为二，气为三。 形体神气具，方乃成人。 又以神为一，气为二，精为三，然后成神。 又以天为一，地为二，人为三，然后成天地道德也。 故云三合成音。 音者，取其声律相协，今本章是也。 文以气而结，神以炁而合，以类相感，故云混合百神。 又紫微上元宫中有延生之符，置之八方则八方之气欻然响应，皆即成人，复藏其符则复化为气是也。 混合则归於一身，故《救苦经》云：真人混无分，天气归一身。 莫非自然之气矣。 天宝诵之，以开天地之光。 灵宝诵之，以开九幽长夜之魂。 神宝诵之，以制万灵。 太一诵之，以具身神。 帝君诵之，以结形。 九天诵之，以生人。 学士诵之，以升天。 道不远人，人之为道而远。 人当其天人合同，本无间别。
chunks.translated_text:
The Master of Ceremonies who stands in the courtyard facing east to recite the *Chapter of Generating Spirits* is none other than the Grand Master of Longevity, the Great Marshal. His surname is Bocheng, his given name Xusheng, and he is a Perfected One of the Highest Clarity. When men respectfully assent and chant with reverence, and women respectfully comply and chant with devotion, distinctions of noble and base are thereby made—much like the difference between jade scepters and clay tiles in poetry.

All the spirits mentioned above are the gods of one’s own body. When the moment is right and the qi is full, the hundred spirits assemble together. Now, the spirits regard qi as their mother, and the spirits are the children of qi. If the spirits can abide in qi, and qi can retain the form, then longevity and enduring vision present no difficulty. Alas, people do not understand this, extinguishing their lives through desire and trivializing existence through profit—how deeply lamentable!

When a person is reborn into the human realm, washing their form in the Great Yang, it shakes heaven and earth, a dignity too great to surpass. The celestial perfected, earthly spirits, and the Three Realms all descend together—such is not taken lightly. At the time of birth, it is not to be deemed mean. Therefore, one who can cherish their form, preserve their spirit, honor their qi, and secure their root will never perish or decay but attain transcendence, their bones and flesh ascending together to the Three Clarities. This is to unite virtue with the Three Qi and align with the Nine Qi.

Yet people, having obtained life, fail to revere their qi, honor their form, preserve their life, or cherish their spirit, bringing about their own decay and separation from their original truth. The *Mystic Origin’s Veiled Charge* states: “Born between heaven and earth, humans receive the harmony of the Two Qi, crown the myriad creatures, dwell in the most numinous place, and gather the essence of the Five Phases. They partake in the Three Powers, standing alongside heaven and earth—truly the most noble without peer. If one attains a human body, one should cherish and protect it, for the boundary between life and death is fraught with delusion. The human body is like standing on a plank while a ball rolls beneath; attaining a human body is like boarding a boat against the current. This is why the Divine King, in his earnest concern, pities sentient beings for their unawareness, their disregard for life, and their submission to death. They do not value the human body and thus raise this question.

Once a human body is attained, it must proceed to the Southern Cinnabar Fire-Refining Pool, where it is cleansed with the Yellow Flower’s waters before entering the womb to become a person. Now, this scripture speaks of washing the form in the Great Yang rather than the Yellow Flower—why? The Yellow Flower is the essence of yang, the upper abode of the sun, also called the Cavern Yang Palace. Within it lies the Flowing Fire Pool, containing the Yellow Flower’s waters. Divine beings constantly bathe their forms in these waters, which is why our teachings, when recommending the deceased, employ the *Longevity Talisman*, pointing to this.

Since becoming human involves so many stages, it is truly what shakes heaven and earth, with the Three Realms descending together—hardly a mean affair. Each time I recite this passage, I close the scroll and sigh deeply. This body stands alongside heaven and earth, its qi communicating with yin and yang. This body is the body of the Three Treasures, this qi the qi of yin and yang. Nothing is more venerable than the Three Treasures, no spirit greater than yin and yang. When their mechanism is set in motion, the myriad things transform accordingly—so how could it not shake heaven and earth, with the Three Realms descending together? Such is no exaggeration.

Having attained this life, one cannot but rejoice—how could it be taken lightly? Yet people do not cherish their form, preserve their spirit, honor their qi, or secure their root to unite virtue with the Three Qi and align with the Nine Qi. This is entirely because selfish desires prevail while wisdom is lacking. How many are like those who would use Marquis Sui’s pearl to shoot a sparrow a thousand fathoms high? Such people are everywhere—how could they not lose their original truth?

The *Nine Heavens’ Chapter of Generating Spirits* is the qi of the Three Caverns’ Flying Mystery, where three coalesce to form sound and congeal into numinous script. It blends the hundred spirits and conceals their inner names, generating qi to structure form—this is the *Chapter of Spontaneity*. The vastness of heaven and earth cannot move without qi; the human body cannot stand without qi; the Three Caverns’ sacred scriptures cannot take form without qi. That it is called the *Chapter of Spontaneity* means it does not originate from human speech.

According to the *Twelve Disciplines of the Great Perfected*, the spontaneous original text is primary, being the teaching of prior heaven. The Nine Heavens’ Elder told the Three Heavens’ Jade Lads: “The *Record in the Cinnabar Womb’s Essence* states that at the inception of generating mystery, the qi of the Great Void’s spontaneity congealed to form sacred script—this is the present *Chapter of Generating Spirits*.” The Flying Mystery refers to the fact that among the Three Qi, the mysterious qi is ultimate. Its qi is like clouds, drifting and circling in the Great Void, coalescing only after threefold union to produce sound.

This threefold union, as the *Scripture of Origins* states: “The human form is one, the body is two, and qi is three. Only when form, body, spirit, and qi are complete does a person come into being.” Alternatively, spirit is one, qi is two, and essence is three—only then is a spirit formed. Or heaven is one, earth is two, and humanity is three—only then are the Dao and virtue of heaven and earth complete. Thus it is said that three coalesce to form sound. “Sound” refers to harmonious tones, as in this very chapter.

Scripture is congealed by qi, spirits are united by qi, and like attracts like—hence it is said to blend the hundred spirits. Moreover, in the Upper Prime Palace of the Purple Tenuity, there is a talisman for extending life. When placed in the eight directions, the qi of the eight directions responds in an instant, and all become human. When the talisman is concealed again, they revert to qi. Blending returns all to one body, which is why the *Scripture of Salvation* states: “The Perfected blend without division, and the celestial qi returns to one body.” All is the spontaneous qi.

Reciting the *Celestial Treasure* opens the light of heaven and earth. Reciting the *Numinous Treasure* opens the souls of the Nine Darks’ long night. Reciting the *Spirit Treasure* governs the myriad spirits. Reciting the *Great One* equips the body’s spirits. Reciting the *Thearch* structures the form. Reciting the *Nine Heavens* generates humanity. Reciting as a scholar ascends to heaven. The Dao is not distant from humanity—it is humanity that distances itself from the Dao. When heaven and humanity unite, there is originally no separation.

chunks.original_text: 以理推之，天宝即元始，灵宝即道君，神宝即老君。 天宝生於龙汉之初，天地乍分，上无复色，下无复渊，溟涬大梵，寥廓无光。 天宝君以自然生神玉章开而辟之，则上下列位，即《度人经》云无文不光是也。 灵宝君生於龙汉开图之初，为度人之首，故云开九幽长夜之魂。 《度人经》云无文不度是也。 神宝君生於赤明元年，万范既张，太虚毓妙，大象炳灵，以阳精之气化生上圣高真，以冲静之气化生元君圣母，刚烈之气化生天丁力士，余气化育万灵，故云以制万灵。 《度人经》云：五文开廓，普殖神灵是也。 制则使其无妄作之威。 即身而言之，天宝君之气处於泥丸，神泄於目而为光，故云开天地之光。 灵宝君之气处绛官，是为灵府血之所生。 血乃阴也，藏之於肝，肝主魂，故云开长夜之魂。 《大洞经》云：为我断塞死户，使上帝玉华固我丹元之乡，披解七祖幽魂，上升南官。 神宝君之气处下丹田，即黄庭也，乃生神之府也。 经云：散化五形变万神，是名黄庭曰内篇。 故云：以制万灵。 太一以总众神，即务犹收也。 帝君则逢陵梵也。 已上即一身之神也。 详解於下。 形既结则四枝五体无不完备，九月神布，将欲成人也。 学道之士能知是理，即三官为三宝，九天齐并，终不死坏，上升九天，其道岂远人邪，息其不为也。 鬼灵闻之，以升迁。 凡夫闻之，以长存。 幽魂闻之，以开度。 枯朽闻之，以发烟。 婴孩闻之，以能言。 死骸闻之，以还人。 自天宝至学士言之，盖得吾道者，上为皇而下为王。 自鬼灵至死骸，言之失吾道者，上见光而下为土。 然诵之与闻之者，固自有间。 盖诵之者以得其道，诵尧之言、行尧之行是也。 今也不幸，不得其道，陷为鬼灵、凡夫，幽魂之列，与道寥远。 一旦归闻是经，在鬼灵者，上可升迁，名入东华，不隶三官之鬼。 谨按《飞仙宝剑经》云：有肖貌之才，绝众之望，既终受三官，书为善爽之鬼，四百年乃得为地下主者，从此以进，三百年为一阶。 今闻是经，不待限期，可以升迁。 凡夫者，六欲具全，是名几夫。 今闻是经，六欲不染，在世长年是也。 幽魂则地狱幽囚之人，今闻是经，度品南官是也。 枯朽者，乃草木也。 枯朽则质不存矣。 今使发烟，是何理耶。 此经乃飞玄之气，结成灵文，世之草木，无过以气而生今也，使之发烟，烟即木之气也。 木中有火，质具乃火然。 今也枯朽，生理不存。 今感是经以气相滋，渐有生质，故云枯朽闻之以发烟。 若以人推之，则丧灵矣。 精者，即枯朽之物也，烟即如人之气，气若不存，岂不为枯朽之物耶。 故东坡和渊明《形影诗》 曰：君如烟上火，火尽君乃别。 经言及此，方知神妙之功，与物无间。 昔重阳曰：有道挈一瓢，内贮大丹，杂之以粟，信手与人。 至日暮粟尽而丹在，乃曰：世人福何鲜耶。 於是将大丹留於玉局枯海棕树上而去，明日视之，海棕再生，枯朽发烟，岂无是理耶。 婴孩者，能啼而不能言，今闻是经即得言语，盖孔窍开聪也。 死骸者，则魂魄各离，人道已远，今闻是经，复过为人。 昔徐甲已死，经历多载。 一旦老君以太玄生符投之再活，彼以符力，此以经力，同归殊途也。 三宝神奥，万品生根，故非鬼神所知，凡夫所能闻也。
chunks.translated_text:
Pursuing this by principle, the Celestial Treasure is the Primordial Beginning, the Numinous Treasure is the Lord of the Dao, and the Spirit Treasure is the Venerable Lord. The Celestial Treasure arose at the dawn of Dragon Han, when heaven and earth first divided—above, no further hue; below, no further abyss—only the vast expanse of primordial chaos, boundless and lightless. The Lord of the Celestial Treasure, by the spontaneous generation of the Jade Chapters of Divine Manifestation, opened and ordered it, so that above and below took their places. Thus the *Scripture of Salvation through the Crossing of All* states: “Where there is no script, there is no illumination.”

The Lord of the Numinous Treasure arose at the inception of the Dragon Han’s unfolding chart, becoming the first to deliver humanity. Hence it is said to open the souls of the Nine Darks’ long night. The *Scripture of Salvation through the Crossing of All* states: “Where there is no script, there is no deliverance.”

The Lord of the Spirit Treasure arose in the first year of Vermilion Brightness, when the myriad patterns were already arrayed, the Great Void nurtured the wondrous, and the great image radiated numinosity. From the qi of yang essence were transformed the lofty perfected and exalted immortals; from the qi of tranquil emptiness were transformed the Primordial Lords and Holy Mothers; from the qi of unyielding vigor were transformed the Heavenly Soldiers and Mighty Warriors; and from the remaining qi were nurtured the myriad spirits. Thus it is said to govern the myriad spirits. The *Scripture of Salvation through the Crossing of All* states: “The five scripts unfold the expanse, universally engendering divine spirits.” To govern is to ensure they wield no reckless power.

Speaking of the body: the qi of the Lord of the Celestial Treasure resides in the Mud-Pill Palace, its spirit issuing from the eyes as light. Thus it is said to open the light of heaven and earth. The qi of the Lord of the Numinous Treasure resides in the Crimson Palace, which is the numinous repository born of blood. Blood is yin, stored in the liver, and the liver governs the hun-soul. Thus it is said to open the souls of the long night. The *Scripture of the Great Cavern* states: “For me, block and seal the Gate of Death, so that the Jade Flower of the Thearch may secure my Cinnabar Prime’s domain. Unbind the seven generations of ancestral souls in darkness, ascending them to the Southern Palace.”

The qi of the Lord of the Spirit Treasure resides in the Lower Cinnabar Field, which is the Yellow Court—the repository of spirit generation. The scripture states: “Dispersing transforms the five forms, transmuting into the myriad spirits.” This is called the “Inner Chapter” of the Yellow Court. Thus it is said to govern the myriad spirits. The Great One unites all spirits, which is to say, it gathers and restrains them. The Thearch is the Meeting of the Brahma-Realm. All the above are the spirits of the one body, explained in detail below.

Once the form is structured, the four limbs and five constituents are all complete. In the ninth month, the spirits are arrayed, and one is about to become human. If a scholar of the Dao understands this principle, the Three Officials become the Three Treasures, and the Nine Heavens converge as one. Thus one will never perish or decay, ascending to the Nine Heavens. How could the Dao be distant from humanity? Cease your inaction.

When ghostly spirits hear this, they ascend and are promoted. When ordinary people hear this, they attain longevity. When souls in darkness hear this, they are delivered and opened. When withered and decayed things hear this, they emit smoke. When infants hear this, they can speak. When dead remains hear this, they return to being human.

From the Celestial Treasure to the scholar: those who attain our Dao become emperors above and kings below. From ghostly spirits to dead remains: those who lose our Dao see light above and become earth below. Yet there is a distinction between reciting and merely hearing. Those who recite attain the Dao—like reciting the words of Yao and practicing the conduct of Yao. Now, alas, failing to attain the Dao, one falls among ghostly spirits, ordinary people, and souls in darkness, far removed from the Dao. Yet if one day they return to hear this scripture: those among ghostly spirits may ascend and be promoted, their names entering the Eastern Florescence, no longer subject to the Three Officials’ ghosts.

According to the *Scripture of the Flying Immortal’s Precious Sword*: “Those with talents resembling the worthy and surpassing the multitude, though they die and are recorded by the Three Officials as good and bright ghosts, must wait four hundred years to become rulers of the underworld. From there, they advance one rank every three hundred years.” Yet upon hearing this scripture, they need not wait for the appointed time to ascend and be promoted.

Ordinary people possess all six desires and are called “near-men.” Upon hearing this scripture, the six desires no longer defile them, and they enjoy long life in the world. Souls in darkness are those imprisoned in the earthly dungeons. Upon hearing this scripture, they are delivered to the ranks of the Southern Palace.

The withered and decayed are plants and trees. Once withered and decayed, their substance no longer remains. Yet how can they emit smoke upon hearing this scripture? This scripture is composed of flying mystery-qi, structured into numinous script. The plants and trees of the world are born of qi. When they emit smoke, smoke is the qi of wood. Within wood lies fire; when substance is present, fire ignites. Now, though withered and decayed, their principle of life is gone. Yet when they encounter this scripture, qi nourishes them, gradually restoring their vital substance. Thus it is said that the withered and decayed emit smoke upon hearing it. If one analogizes to humans, it is the loss of spirit.

The refined is the withered and decayed thing; smoke is like a person’s qi. If qi no longer remains, is this not a withered and decayed thing? Thus Su Dongpo, harmonizing with Yuanming’s *Poems on Form and Shadow*, wrote: “You are like fire upon smoke; when the fire is spent, you depart.” Only upon reaching this point in the scripture does one realize the wondrous efficacy of the divine, which admits no separation from things.

Formerly, Chongyang said: “One who possesses the Dao carries a gourd, within which is the Great Elixir, mixed with grains. He gives it freely to others. By day’s end, the grains are gone, but the elixir remains. He then says: ‘How meager is the world’s good fortune!’ Thereupon, he leaves the Great Elixir on the withered sea-palm at the Jade Bureau and departs. The next day, he sees the sea-palm revived, the withered and decayed emitting smoke. Is this not the same principle?”

Infants can cry but cannot speak. Upon hearing this scripture, they gain speech, for their orifices open and their faculties sharpen. Dead remains are those whose hun and po souls have each departed, far removed from the human way. Upon hearing this scripture, they return to being human. Formerly, Xu Jia had already died, passing many years. One day, the Venerable Lord cast the Talisman of Great Mystery upon him, reviving him. That was by the power of the talisman; this is by the power of the scripture—different paths converging in the same end.

The Three Treasures are the profound mystery, the root of the myriad beings. Thus they are not known by ghosts and spirits, nor heard by ordinary people.

chunks.original_text: 三宝者，即天宝、灵宝、神宝是也。 生天生地，神鬼神帝，至静而不变，至纯而不杂，覆至大之天地而无所遗，藏至幽之鬼神而弗能状。 万品芸芸，消息不已而不可穷，可谓神奥矣。 故经曰：道者，万物之奥。 三宝者，又道之奥也。 奥者，深邃之地，大本大宗之所由焉。 《太玄》曰：天奥西北，郁化精也。 地奥黄泉，隐营魄也。 人奥思虑，蕴至神也。 又《南华经》曰：祥生於奥。 旧疏以未为奥，言坤也。 今《太玄》指黄即坤也。 大梵之气起自西北，生物者咸往资焉，乃立天之道也。 魄营於坤，品物咸亨，立地之道也。 天地既立，阴阳乃备。 生者不得不生，化者不得不化，故云三宝神奥，万品生根。 前云鬼灵闻之以升迁，凡夫闻之以长存，今又云非鬼神所知，凡夫所能闻。 若鬼神未知之前，凡夫未闻之日，与既知既闻之后，故自有间，不可同日而语也。 得是道者，不可致诂。 岂闻世俗常闻耶，至言不可苟得，神仙之道鲜矣。 夫学上道，希慕神仙，及得尸解，灭度转轮，终归仙道，形与神同，不相远离，俱入道真。 而无此文，则胞胎结滞，死气固根，真景不守，生气无津，九户阂塞，体不生神，徒受一形，若寄气而行。 学得此法，可坐致自然。 夫上真之道有七，太上之道有三，中真之道有六，下真之道有八。 《生神章经》，其义与《大洞三十九章》相为表裹。 今考《大洞三十九章》，系上真之道，故云上道。 夫学上道，希慕神仙者，恐其力量蹇浅，未能带骨上升，止得尸解。 且以灭度转轮，若转轮未息，则生死之根犹在，未免六道循环。 故青童君曰：欲植灭度根，当拔生死栽，沉吟坠九泉，但坐惜形骸。 生死栽者，转轮是也。 若入转轮，恐乖人道，难复人身。 人身尚且难复，则希慕神仙者，愈更并越已。 今经言尸解者，方免转轮，终会仙道。 然功行未充，鬼录有名，不免三官追摄，故暂寄形於嵌嵓穷谷之间，令太一守尸，三魂营骨，七魄护肉，胎灵结气，久久更生。 且尸解之道，方法多门，服刀圭而虫流，漱流胎而次死，饮琼浆而叩棺，服金丹而告终，或头尸异处，身脱发存，大抵一生未就故也。 是以仙公七世而登真，太极百身而证果。 既作尸解，叉以生神之章，以固其尸形，则生津不涸，而死户闭矣。 《列纪经》云：人之一体所以死烂者，有三十九处，以受鬼气，形有间孔，血有亏迭，死气日进，邪气引入，精神不通，津液沉滞，百神奔走。 故经言死气固根，真景不守，生气无津是也。 真景者，真神也。 徒受一形，若寄气而行。 虽有此身，不晓生神之道，何异行尸邪。 若得此法，可坐政自然。 此专指《生神经》为捷径，不作尸解，直入大乘而言也。 此法何在。 经曰：
chunks.translated_text:
The Three Treasures are the Heavenly Treasure, the Numinous Treasure, and the Divine Treasure. They give birth to Heaven and Earth, empower ghosts and gods, emperors and lords. Utterly quiescent yet unchanging, utterly pure yet unadulterated, they cover the vastness of Heaven and Earth without omission, conceal the depths of ghosts and spirits beyond all description. The ten thousand kinds teem and transform without cease, unfathomable—truly they may be called the profound mystery.

Thus the scripture says: “The Dao/Way is the mystery of the myriad things.” The Three Treasures are the mystery within the mystery. “Mystery” is the deep and secluded place, the source of the Great Root and Great Ancestor.

The *Canon of Supreme Mystery* says: “The mystery of Heaven lies in the northwest, where essence transforms in dense abundance. The mystery of Earth lies in the Yellow Springs, where the po soul is concealed and nurtured. The mystery of Man lies in thought, where the utmost spirit is stored.”

The *Scripture of Southern Florescence* says: “Auspiciousness arises from the mystery.” The old commentary takes “wei” as the mystery, meaning Kun. Here, the *Canon of Supreme Mystery* points to the Yellow as Kun. The qi of Great Brahmā arises from the northwest; all living things turn to it for sustenance—this is the Dao/Way of establishing Heaven. The po soul is nurtured in Kun, and the ten thousand kinds all flourish—this is the Dao/Way of establishing Earth. Once Heaven and Earth are established, yin and yang are complete. That which is born cannot but be born; that which transforms cannot but transform. Thus it is said: the Three Treasures are the profound mystery, the root of the myriad beings.

Earlier it was said that ghosts and spirits hear this and ascend, while ordinary people hear it and attain longevity. Now it is said that they are not known by ghosts and spirits, nor heard by ordinary people. Before ghosts and spirits knew it, before ordinary people had heard it, and after they have known and heard it—these are not the same, and cannot be spoken of in the same breath.

Those who attain this Dao/Way cannot be fully explicated. How could it be grasped by the commonplace hearing of the world? The utmost words cannot be casually obtained; the Dao/Way of immortals and transcendents is rare indeed.

Those who study the supreme Dao/Way, yearning for immortals and transcendents, may achieve liberation through the corpse when their power and capacity are shallow, unable to ascend with their bones. This is called “extinction and turning the wheel.” If the turning of the wheel has not ceased, the root of life and death remains, and one is not free from the cycle of the six destinies.

Thus the Azure Lad said:
*“To plant the root of extinction,*
*Uproot the seed of life and death.*
*Lamenting, you sink into the nine springs—*
*All for cherishing the bodily frame.”*

The seed of life and death is the turning wheel. If one enters the turning wheel, one may stray from the human way and find it difficult to regain a human form. If even a human form is hard to regain, how much more so for those who yearn for immortals and transcendents?

Yet this scripture speaks of liberation through the corpse as a means to escape the turning wheel and ultimately join the immortal Dao/Way. However, if one’s merit and conduct are not yet full, one’s name remains in the ghostly registers, and one is not free from the pursuit of the Three Offices. Thus, one temporarily lodges the form in the clefts of cliffs and the depths of valleys, where the Great Unity guards the corpse, the three hun souls tend the bones, the seven po souls protect the flesh, and the embryonic spirit binds the qi. Over time, one is reborn.

Moreover, the Dao/Way of liberation through the corpse has many methods: ingesting the elixir knife and worms flow out; rinsing with the flow of the embryo and dying in stages; drinking jade nectar and knocking on the coffin; consuming the golden elixir and announcing the end. Some leave their heads in one place and their bodies in another; some shed their bodies while their hair remains. In general, this is because their cultivation in a single lifetime was not complete. Thus, the Immortal Duke attained perfection after seven generations, and the Supreme Ultimate achieved fruition after a hundred bodies.

Once one has achieved liberation through the corpse, one employs the *Chapter on Generating the Spirit* to secure the bodily form. Then the vital fluids do not dry up, and the gates of death close. The *Scripture of Arrayed Records* says: “The reason a human body decays and rots is that there are thirty-nine places where it receives ghostly qi. The form has interstices, the blood has deficiencies, the dead qi advances daily, and perverse qi is drawn in. The spirit and essence do not circulate, the fluids stagnate, and the hundred spirits flee.” Thus the scripture speaks of the dead qi fixing the root, the true radiance not being preserved, and the vital qi lacking its springs.

The “true radiance” is the true spirit. To merely receive a single form, drifting along as if borrowing qi—though one has this body, if one does not understand the Dao/Way of generating the spirit, how is this different from a walking corpse?

If one attains this method, one may sit and govern the natural. This refers specifically to the *Scripture of Generating the Spirit* as a shortcut, bypassing liberation through the corpse and directly entering the Great Vehicle.

Where is this method found? The scripture says:

The Three Treasures are the profound mystery, the root of the myriad beings. Thus they are not known by ghosts and spirits, nor heard by ordinary people.

chunks.original_text: 《九天生神章》乃三洞飞玄之气，三合成音，结成灵文，混合百神。 人之一身，莫非三气之所生，既受此气，则与元始为一，便可混合百神，气之所在，神即随之。 初以三气生三神，三部八景，则为二十四神，若常混合二十四神，变化三五真人，混成正一，合为帝君。 虽百千万亿之多，亦能混合，则乎阳召阴，出入无方，阳气化为龙车，阴气变为玉女，舞轮空玄之上，坐致自然，岂欺我哉。 三宝尊重，九天至真。 秘之大有九重金格紫阳玉台。 自非天地一开，其文不出。 元始禁书，非鬼神所闻。 窃之者风刀万劫，魂死无生，依科尊奉，形神同仙。 圣人济物之心，无时而已，然处於万天之上，世孰得而知之。 故以三洞之经，流布人问，莫非圣人之心声也。 今诵其经，即得其心，因其心而会诸圣，其经见在，即圣人之见在也。 可不重欤。 《 生神经》 乃天地之祖气，群生之父母，三宝犹自重之，况於人乎。 酆都六洞宫中有专治诽谤三宝大乘之罪，其经乃三宝之言也，不重其言，则与诽谤奚异。 九天至真。 至者，上也。 秘之大有。 乃藏经之所也。 谨按《七变舞天经》载：上清宝经三百卷、玉诀九千篇、符图七千章，及自然之章，秘在九天之上，大有之宫。 大有之宫，乃玉清宫也。 又按《金真玉光经》：九重金格紫阳玉台，九重乃缄鐍之深也，格则几案之类。 按《道宝经》有玉格焉、金格焉，二者皆属九天。 三关之上有玉台，台上有玉格，安上皇太真高帝玉名之处也。 详此不惟重之，又且秘文。 不由龙汉开图，神王冒禁恳请，则此文岂得而见之。 宜乎窃之者受罪，尊奉者同仙。 窃之者良可为戒，奉之者可不勉哉。 三元宫中，宿有金名，紫字刻书，来生应为三清神仙之人，当得此文。 有其缘会，当赉金宝奉师，效心依科盟受，闭心奉行，慎勿轻泄，风刀考身。 三元考校，不独死魂而已。 几得道者，与未得道者，皆预焉。 惟金名紫字，常以旌别学仙之人，故藏中所载，三元考官地狱之品，谓之墨录。 则得金名紫字者，诚与之有间矣。 昔李珏，江阳之小民也。 其功行久在仙籍，虽未得登天，然姓名已用金书於华阳洞天矣。 不特学仙之士品格有如此者。 世书梁元帝为湘东王时，尝记录忠臣义士及文章之美者，以三品笔书之，忠孝者用金管，德行者用银管，文章美者用班竹管。 《太上玉诀经》云：紫微宫中有金格玉书，赤金书，青玉简，皆此类也。 若人宿植善功，尽此报身，来生当为三清神仙之人，自然与此经相值，必次赉金宝，依科盟受，方可修行，如其不然，必有风刀之考。 三复斯言，此皆为中小乘设也。 风刀之考，盖屡言之前章，载风刀万劫，魂死无生，后云风刀相刑，可不慎焉。 独中间飞天神王受拜之时，元始天尊谓曰：宝书秘重，九天灵音，施於上圣，非鬼神所闻。 明真有格，四万劫一传，今冒禁相付，子秘之矣，慎勿轻传。 其词止於慎勿轻传而已。 风刀之考，岂不为中小乘人设耶。 《太上科令》云：传受天书而钟其殃祖先者，是重其宣言之罪，防其漏泄之盟。 尔所以黑录上篇载水火官，外又有风刀左右二官。 左风考官，主治受经符宝诀，无盟修行，受财卖道，将损天科之罪／o 右刀考官，治伏誓告盟，背违师友，去彼适此，评论善恶，攻伐根本，莫大之罪。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Nine Heavens’ Scripture of Generating the Spirit* is the flying mystery-qi of the Three Caverns, the threefold harmony that forms sound and coalesces into numinous script. It blends the hundred spirits as one. Within the human body, nothing is not born of these three qi. Once one receives this qi, one unites with the Primordial Beginning, thereby merging with the hundred spirits—where qi resides, spirit follows.

At first, the three qi generate the three spirits; the three divisions and eight luminaries become the twenty-four spirits. If one constantly merges with the twenty-four spirits, one transforms into the Three-Five Perfected, coalescing into the Orthodox Unity and uniting as the Thearch Lord. Though their number be a hundred thousand myriad millions, one may still merge with them. Thus yang summons yin, and they move without fixed direction. Yang qi transforms into dragon chariots, yin qi becomes jade maidens, dancing upon the wheels of the empty mystery, seated to attain spontaneity—how could this be deception?

The Three Treasures are revered, the Nine Heavens’ Perfected are supreme. The secrecy is profound, sealed within ninefold golden lattices and the Purple Yang Jade Terrace. Unless heaven and earth are newly opened, its text does not emerge. It is the Primordial Beginning’s forbidden scripture, not for the hearing of ghosts and spirits. Whoever steals it suffers the wind-blades for ten thousand kalpas, their souls dying without rebirth. Those who uphold the precepts and revere it attain immortality in both form and spirit.

The sagely heart of aiding beings knows no end, yet it abides above the myriad heavens—who in the world could know it? Thus the scriptures of the Three Caverns are disseminated among humanity, for they are none other than the sagely heart’s voice. To recite this scripture now is to attain that heart, and through that heart to commune with all sages. Since the scripture exists, the sages exist as well—how could it not be revered?

The *Scripture of Generating the Spirit* is the ancestral qi of heaven and earth, the parent of all living beings. Even the Three Treasures hold it in reverence—how much more should humans? In the Six Caverns of Fengdu’s palaces, there is a special tribunal for the crime of slandering the Mahāyāna of the Three Treasures. This scripture is the speech of the Three Treasures; to slight its words is no different from slander. The Nine Heavens’ Perfected are supreme.

“Supreme” means highest. “The secrecy is profound” refers to the repository of the scriptures. According to the *Seven Transformations’ Dance of Heaven Scripture*, the Supreme Clarity’s treasured scriptures number three hundred scrolls, the jade instructions nine thousand chapters, the talismanic diagrams seven thousand sections, along with the scriptures of spontaneity—all are concealed above the Nine Heavens in the Palace of Great Existence. The Palace of Great Existence is the Jade Clarity Palace.

Further, according to the *Golden Perfection and Jade Radiance Scripture*, the ninefold golden lattices and Purple Yang Jade Terrace—“ninefold” denotes the depth of the seals, while “lattice” refers to a kind of desk or stand. As the *Scripture of the Daoist Treasure* states, there are jade lattices and golden lattices, both belonging to the Nine Heavens. Above the Three Passes is the Jade Terrace, upon which rests the jade lattice where the Supreme August Perfected’s golden name is placed. This is not only revered but also a secret text. Unless the Dragon Han opens the charts and the Divine Kings risk transgression to earnestly entreat, how could one behold this scripture? Thus those who steal it incur punishment, while those who revere it attain immortality. Those who steal it should indeed take warning, and those who revere it should strive diligently.

In the Three Primes’ palaces, those whose golden names are recorded and whose purple characters are inscribed in the registers are destined in their next lives to become Perfected Immortals of the Three Clarities. When the karmic conditions align, they should present golden treasures to their masters, sincerely follow the precepts, and receive the scripture through covenant. They must guard their hearts and practice diligently, taking care never to leak it lightly, lest the wind-blades examine their bodies. The Three Primes’ judgment extends not only to the dead souls but to all—both those who have attained the Dao/Way and those who have not. Only those with golden names and purple characters are distinguished as students of immortality. Thus, in the records of the repositories, the Three Primes’ judging officials and the ranks of hell are called the “Ink Registers.” Those with golden names and purple characters are truly set apart from them.

Formerly, Li Jue was a commoner of Jiangyang. His merit and conduct had long been recorded in the immortal registers. Though he had not yet ascended to heaven, his name was already inscribed in gold in the Huayang Grotto-Heaven. Not only students of immortality possess such distinctions. In secular records, when Emperor Yuan of Liang was Prince of Xiangdong, he once recorded loyal ministers, righteous scholars, and those with fine literary works, inscribing them with three grades of brushes: loyal and filial ones with golden tubes, those of virtuous conduct with silver tubes, and those with fine literature with mottled bamboo tubes.

The *Supreme Jade Instructions Scripture* states: In the Purple Tenuity Palace are golden lattices and jade books, red-gold writings, and azure jade tablets—all of this kind. If one has planted good roots in past lives and exhausted this karmic body, in the next life one will become a Perfected Immortal of the Three Clarities. Naturally, one will encounter this scripture, and one must then present golden treasures, follow the precepts, and receive it through covenant before one may cultivate. Otherwise, one will surely face the wind-blades’ examination.

These words bear repeating, for they are established for the intermediate and lesser vehicles. The wind-blades’ examination has been mentioned repeatedly in previous chapters: “the wind-blades for ten thousand kalpas, souls dying without rebirth,” and later, “the wind-blades’ mutual punishment”—how could one not be cautious?

When the Flying Heavenly Divine Kings received the obeisance, the Primordial Heavenly Venerable said to them: “The treasured scripture is profoundly secret, the numinous sounds of the Nine Heavens, bestowed upon the supreme sages—not for the hearing of ghosts and spirits. The Perfected’s lattices are revealed once every forty thousand kalpas. Now, transgressing the prohibition, I entrust it to you—guard it well, and never transmit it lightly.” These words only caution against careless transmission. Is not the wind-blades’ examination established for those of the intermediate and lesser vehicles?

The *Celestial Precepts of the Supreme* state: “Those who transmit celestial scriptures and bring calamity upon their ancestors incur the grave sin of violating their proclamations, preventing the breach of their covenants.” Thus, the upper chapter of the *Black Register* records the Water and Fire Officials, and beyond them, the Wind-Blade Left and Right Officials. The Left Wind Examiner oversees those who receive scriptures, talismans, treasured instructions, or precepts without covenant, who cultivate for profit, sell the Dao/Way, or violate celestial statutes. The Right Blade Examiner governs those who break their vows, betray their masters and friends, abandon one for another, judge good and evil, or attack the root—none greater than these sins.

chunks.original_text: 与《太霄琅书》遇贤便传，不拘定数者，相去远矣。 修行之法，千日长斋，不关人事，诸尘漏尽，夷心默念，清香执戒，入室东向，叩齿九通，调声正气，诵咏宝章。 招真以炼形，形清则气合，含道以炼气，气清则神怡，此长斋之法也。 《庄子》 云：宇泰定者，发乎天光。 宇秦定者，夷心是也。 生神之旨，无出於此。 舍此之外，莫非人事。 众生之心，未齐之时，心如游尘，与物相刃相靡，风驰而火炽，渐染尘垢，无时暂止。 既斋之后，神气归一，盖神者在耳，而听在目，而视在舌，而味在心，而变化在意，而倏忽其神，长游於六根。 今也六根不纳，诸尘漏尽，教中有八漏：目之泪，肝漏。 鼻之涕，肺漏。 。 之唾，肾漏。 外汗，心漏。 夜盗汗，小肠漏。 寝而涎者，脑漏。 梦与鬼交，神漏。 淫欲者，身漏。 已上诸漏，无非五荫六入，十二根尘之所交接。 若使形充空虚，聪止於耳，心止於符，则诸尘无自而入也。 昔葛仙公长齐於天台山，未经一年，遂致感通，上圣曲眄幽房。 后人修斋之法，始原於此。 严真君云：虚心以原道德，静意以期神明。 缘众生之心，未合於道，先授之以斋法，使其因斋而息心，息心而入道，后世炽以人事，涉以形器，而视斋法，盖何谬邪。 祭酒道士，只成一尸祝矣。 入室东向，取生气也，调声所以正气，玄感所以集神，皆诵经之节要也。 诵之一过，声闻九天。 诵之二过，天地设恭。 诵之三过，三界礼房。 诵之四过，天王降仙。 谓之五过，五帝朝真。 诵之六过，魔王束身。 诵之七过，星宿停关。 诵之八过，幽夜光明。 诵之九过，诸天下临，一切神灵，莫不卫轩。 前章载修行之法，莫非返身成诚之说。 既能返身，则与天为一，则是知天之所为，知人之所为者至矣。 所谓至者，和同天人之际，使之无间，故诵经至於一过，声闻九天。 诵之在此，闻之於彼，言其上下察也。 二过，天地设恭。 《度人经》有天地设礼，其义大同。 盖恭之与礼，轻重之别，恭而能礼，方见尽善。 至於三过，三界礼房，则知礼字又过於恭也。 四过天王降仙，经中有法王、天王之号，莫非高圣之尊称。 降仙则感会神仙来集其所，如葛仙公研思斋法，感召太极仙人徐来勒降於静室之中是也。 五过，五帝朝真。 如魏夫人道成之时，五老帝君降於其室，传以五帝策杖之类。 六过魔王束身，《卫灵咒》有魔王束首身首之分，字虽不同，其理则一。 束字训缚。 至於六遍，魔王始束其身，不令妄动，恐生干试。 学道之士，魔试甚多，初历子魔，后历大魔，二试若过，魔王方能保举，上登仙品。 且魔王束身不於五过、七过，至於六数，功方及之，何耶。 盖六天大魔乃六天故气，谓之至阴之鬼帅，其力量与天齐同，元始命化其魔并生。 故道家经语斋醮之法，必先制之，然后成功。 六为老阴，其威盛大，是以斋法必先午时命魔，谓此者也。 一阴生於午，故先杜其渐，若后时而作，必不救也。 每见黄坛上十案香，初夜宿启，始於正北，乃子位也。 如修炼大丹，叉以一阳之候发火，次第而历六，乃束北艮位，正当鬼地，乃六魔所居之方。 此浮山玉蟾子命魔之法，昧者不晓其说，止为命地魔，殊不知六洞大魔，即上天之大魔也。
chunks.translated_text:
The transmission of the *Luminous Writ of the Great Empyrean*—where one imparts it upon encountering the worthy without fixed number—differs greatly from this. The method of cultivation requires a thousand-day fast, disengagement from worldly affairs, the cessation of all sensory leaks, a mind stilled to silence, the holding of incense and precepts, entry into the chamber facing east, nine knocks of the teeth, the modulation of voice to rectify qi, and the recitation of sacred scriptures. One summons the perfected to refine the body; when the body is purified, qi harmonizes. One embraces the Dao/Way to refine qi; when qi is purified, the spirit rejoices. Such is the method of the long fast.

As *Zhuangzi* states: “When the cosmos is at peace and settled, the radiance of heaven emerges.” The settled cosmos refers to the stilled mind. The essence of generating the spirit lies in nothing beyond this. All else is but worldly affairs. Before the minds of beings are aligned, the heart drifts like floating dust, clashing and grinding with things, racing like wind and blazing like fire, gradually stained by the dust of the world, never ceasing for a moment. After the fast, spirit and qi return to unity. For the spirit resides in the ears to hear, in the eyes to see, in the tongue to taste, in the heart to transform, and in the intent to shift swiftly—ever roaming among the six senses. Now, with the six senses unengaged and all sensory leaks stanched, the teachings speak of eight leaks: tears from the eyes, a leak of the liver; mucus from the nose, a leak of the lungs; saliva from the mouth, a leak of the kidneys; external sweat, a leak of the heart; night sweats, a leak of the small intestine; drooling in sleep, a leak of the brain; dreams of coupling with ghosts, a leak of the spirit; and lust, a leak of the body. All these leaks arise from the interplay of the five aggregates, six senses, and twelve sense-realms. If the body is filled with emptiness, hearing confined to the ears, and the mind fixed upon the talisman, then the sensory realms have no means of entry.

Of old, Master Ge fasted for a thousand days on Mount Tiantai. Before a year had passed, he achieved resonance, and the lofty sages deigned to glance into his secluded chamber. Later generations’ methods of fasting trace their origin to this. Lord Yan the Perfected said: “Empty the heart to seek virtue/power; still the intent to await the numinous.” Since the hearts of beings have not yet merged with the Dao/Way, they are first taught the method of fasting, that through fasting they may quiet the heart, and through quieting the heart enter the Dao/Way. Yet later ages have inflamed it with worldly affairs, entangled it with form and instrument, and thus regard the fasting method—how grievously mistaken! The libationer-daoists have become mere corpse-invocators.

Facing east upon entering the chamber draws upon the qi of life. Modulating the voice rectifies qi; profound resonance gathers the spirit—all essential elements of scripture recitation. Reciting once, the sound ascends to the nine heavens. Reciting twice, heaven and earth display reverence. Reciting thrice, the three realms bow to the chamber. Reciting four times, the Heavenly Kings descend as immortals. Reciting five times, the Five Emperors attend the perfected. Reciting six times, the Demon Kings bind themselves. Reciting seven times, the stellar constellations halt their gates. Reciting eight times, the darkest night is illuminated. Reciting nine times, all heavens descend, and every spirit and numen shields the chamber with their chariots.

The preceding chapter on cultivation methods speaks of nothing but returning to the body to perfect sincerity. Once one can return to the body, one becomes one with heaven, thereby attaining the utmost knowledge of heaven’s workings and humanity’s workings. The “utmost” refers to the harmonization of the boundary between heaven and humanity, rendering it seamless. Thus, reciting once, the sound ascends to the nine heavens—uttered here, heard there, signifying the scrutiny of above and below. Reciting twice, heaven and earth display reverence. The *Scripture of Salvation* speaks of heaven and earth offering rites, its meaning largely the same. Yet “reverence” and “rites” differ in weight; only when reverence gives rise to rites is perfection attained. Reciting thrice, the three realms bow to the chamber, showing that “rites” surpass “reverence.” Reciting four times, the Heavenly Kings descend as immortals. The scriptures contain titles such as Dharma King and Heavenly King, all exalted appellations of the lofty sages. “Descending as immortals” refers to the summoning of divine immortals to gather at the site, as when Master Ge studied the fasting method and beckoned the Primordial Immortal Xu Laile to descend into his quiet chamber.

Reciting five times, the Five Emperors attend the perfected, as when Lady Wei attained the Dao/Way and the Five Elderly Lords descended to her chamber, transmitting to her the Five Emperors’ staffs of authority. Reciting six times, the Demon Kings bind themselves. The *Guardian Numinous Incantation* speaks of the Demon Kings binding their heads and bodies—though the wording differs, the principle is the same. “Bind” means to restrain. Only after six recitations do the Demon Kings begin to restrain themselves, preventing reckless movement lest they provoke trials. Those who study the Dao/Way face many demonic trials: first the lesser trials of the Zi hour, then the great trials. Only after passing these two trials will the Demon Kings vouch for them, allowing ascent to the immortal ranks.

Yet the Demon Kings do not bind themselves at five or seven recitations, but only at six—why? The great demons of the six heavens are the residual qi of the six heavens, known as the supreme yin ghost-lords, their power equal to that of heaven. The Primordial Beginning commanded their creation along with the demons. Thus, the methods of fasting and offering in Daoist scriptures must first subdue them before success can be achieved. Six is the number of old yin, its might vast and great; hence, the fasting method must first command the demons at the Wu hour. This is the reason: the first yin arises at Wu, so one must first block its inception; if one acts too late, it cannot be remedied.

Often seen at yellow altars with ten cases of incense, the initial night’s vigil begins in the north, the position of Zi. When refining the great elixir, one ignites the fire at the moment of first yang, proceeding through the six positions to the northeast, the Gen direction—precisely the ghostly realm, the abode of the six demons. This is Master Yuchan of Floating Mountain’s method of commanding demons. The unenlightened mistake it for merely commanding earthly demons, unaware that the great demons of the six caverns are none other than the great demons of the heavens above.

chunks.original_text: 汉天师时，分别人鬼，先自驱逐六天魔鬼，令归北酆。 虽曰酆都六洞，寔天界也。 不可以方所泥之。 北都罗酆虽至阴之地，其中亦有六洞仙官，常考算学仙之士，通理三界之籍。 如《度人经》云：阿人歌洞章，以摄北罗酆。 既歌洞章，与酆都有何相涉。 叉日摄北罗酆者，此罗酆之魔，寔群魔之首也。 下云束送妖魔精，斩诚六鬼锋。 其义甚分明。 又今命魔咒后，有三天运明，六天运终，全不晓何等语。 既日命魔，所命何事，强作聪明者甚多。 近看《通教集》，其承习可知。 然玉蟾子教人口口相传，不可载於毫楮，恐生泄漏，予亦不敢妄言之。 七过星宿停关，元始天尊说《度人经》时，城玑玉衡，一时停轮。 本经乃谓之停关，盖指斗柄而言也。 北斗第七号天关星，亦曰破军，所指之方，鬼神避位，行法之家，谓之刚气是也。 八过幽夜光明，至阴之所，日月不照，况魂滞爽，何以升度。 此李若冲诵之，以荐张丽华是也。 九过诸天下临，一切神灵，莫不卫轩。 九过既备，功德所感，尸居而龙见，渊默而雷声，有不期然而然者。 昔李顺兴常诵《大洞经》，积之三年，忽於一夕，有飞仙千数集於空中，神光照室。 作之於此，应之於彼，岂得而诬焉。 一过彻天，胞原宣通。
chunks.translated_text:
During the time of the Han Celestial Master, distinctions were made between humans and ghosts, first by driving away the demons of the Six Heavens and consigning them to Northern Feng. Though called the Six Caverns of Fengdu, they are in truth celestial realms—one must not cling to their earthly locations. Within the Northern Capital of Luo Feng, the land of utmost yin, there also reside the immortal officials of the Six Caverns, who constantly examine and tally the records of those studying the immortal arts, governing the registers of the Three Realms. As the *Scripture of Salvation* states: "The A-ren sings the Cavern Chapters to subdue Northern Luo Feng." Since the Cavern Chapters are sung, what connection do they have with Fengdu? Yet when it says "subdue Northern Luo Feng," it refers to the demons of Luo Feng, who are in fact the chiefs of all demons. The following line, "Expel and dispatch the demonic essences, sever the blades of the Six Ghosts," makes its meaning abundantly clear. Moreover, after the incantation for commanding demons, phrases such as "the Three Heavens revolve in brightness" and "the Six Heavens come to their end" appear—yet none understand their import. Since it is called "commanding demons," what is being commanded? Many feign wisdom in vain.

Recently, in the *Comprehensive Teachings Collection*, the transmitted practices can be discerned. However, Master Yuchan’s oral teachings were passed down from mouth to mouth and never committed to writing, lest they be leaked. I dare not speak of them recklessly.

**Seven Passings: The Stellar Lodge Halts the Barrier**
When the Most High Lord of the Dao expounded the *Scripture of Salvation*, the Celestial Pivot and Jade Balance halted their turning for a time. This scripture refers to it as "halting the barrier," alluding to the handle of the Dipper. The seventh star of the Northern Dipper is called the Celestial Barrier Star, also known as Po Jun. The direction it points is where ghosts and spirits retreat, and practitioners of the Dao call this "the unyielding qi."

**Eight Passings: The Radiance of the Dark Night**
In the place of utmost yin, where neither sun nor moon shines, how can stagnant souls ascend and be delivered? This was the method Li Ruochong used to offer prayers for Zhang Lihua.

**Nine Passings: The Descent of All Heavens**
All divine spirits, without exception, attend in reverence. Once the Nine Passings are complete, the merit thus accrued is such that the corpse abides while the dragon appears, the abyss is silent while thunder resounds—these are things that arise spontaneously, not by design. Long ago, Li Shunxing recited the *Great Cavern Scripture* for three years. One night, suddenly, thousands of flying immortals gathered in the sky, their divine radiance illuminating his chamber. What is cultivated here manifests there—how could this be mere deception?

**One Passing: Penetrating the Heavens**
The primordial womb and its origins are fully opened and made clear.

The unenlightened mistake it for merely commanding earthly demons, unaware that the great demons of the six caverns are none other than the great demons of the heavens above.

chunks.original_text: 道之真以治身，诸余以为国家，土苴以治天下，必先身以及物，此修身之序也。 然此经自千日长斋，不关人事，诸尘漏尽，夷心默念，然后记诵经之过数，有感物之品功，下至此章，亦记九过，始及於身，岂先后失序耶。 盖修行之法，有自内及外者，有自外及内者。 自内及外者，修之身，其德乃真。 有自外及内者，后其身而身先。 详味经旨，与前章不少差异。 但当时一过之功，声闻九天，又能胞原宣通，其理自是两说，所以别而纪之。 如《度人经》说经一遍，诸天大圣同时称善，后至十遍，枯骨更生，皆起成人，此记十遍之功也。 其次又云：说经一遍，东方无极无量品，至真大神无鞅之众，浮空而至，此纪感发之义也。 与此经所纪先后一同，学者不可执一而求之。 一过彻天，胞原宣通。 乃指人受生之始也。 至乎九过，关节本始，一时生神，则又示人以修身之说也。 谓之生神章，其意始见。 盖人未生时，谓之不睹光明，处冥冥之中，无所作用，虽无烦恼系系，使经千百劫，祇成游魂苦爽，何益於事。 虽庄子悲在冶之金，盖惜其为人之后，空与草木腐烂，不若不生之为安也。 学者不悟，便执以为口实，谈长生者，指为疣赘，诚为教中之罪人也。 此乃修行不至，中道而夭，得以藉口，岂足贵哉。 有人於此，不贵其生，认四大为逆旅，忍渴不饮，忍饥不食，无术以御寒，无法而致饱，形骸枯悴，口说苦空，坐待至死。 譬如有屋，拆而露居，身本无病，饮药使病，此岂人之情也哉。 若执之以为然，则乾坤几乎息矣。 天尊神王，愍斯人之倒见，於是区区述生神章，令悟此身与天地并生。 若能因其所生，修其所当生，即长生之道也。 若也不然，则庄子在冶之金，又可悲也。 邵康节诗云：但教枉死一千遍，恰似不曾生一般。 人之受生，以精血为胞，寄於母宫三百日，胎始完具。 精血才胞之初，便有一黄演之气，为之生端。 使其宣通其气，升降不失其度，则生理有渐。 若也胞源不通，则中道夭阏者有焉。 故《太丹隐书》云：若太一凝结者，九气止不变，三一悲而不摄，所以致其死气运入，无得而成也。 二过响地，胎结解根。 天一地二，天地之数也。 声发响应，阳唱阴和也。 人之初生，二月成胎，乃形兆之始。 然生者死之根，胎形既具，有死气故根为之结固，所以因胎而亡、在胎而死者，往往有之。 故二章云：斩根断死户，熙夷养婴童。 若胎根既解，生理渐成，如太一帝君解三关十二结符，以朱书於青竹膜中，用之解结是也。 见《上清洞玄经》。 三过神化，魂门练仙。 天一生水，在人为精，天三生木，在人为魂。 正当三过，魂始具矣。 《玉芝仙经》 云：人之在胎，三月而阴阳分。 阴阳既分，左则生魂，右则生魄，此必然之理。 修行之士，必先拘魂而制魄。 魂乃汞之属，魄乃铅之党。 汞性易飞，人才死则魂先去。 《度人经》云：高上清灵爽，悲歌朗太空。 盖伤人之死也。 人之受胎，魂具则质成，谓之太素门，则分阴阳出入也。 左为魂门，右为魄户。 魂既受炼，则死者可以为生，生者可以成仙，故须延天，谓之明仙之气是也。 炼字，乃缯练也，经中多从此字，不从炼字，意谓太素也，人之生本，本立而道生。
chunks.translated_text:
The true essence of the Dao is for the cultivation of the self; what remains may be applied to the state, and what is left over may be used to govern the world. One must first perfect the self before extending to others—this is the proper sequence of self-cultivation.

Yet this scripture requires a thousand-day fast, detachment from worldly affairs, and the complete cessation of all defilements. Only then, with a mind stilled and thoughts silent, can one commit to memory the number of recitations, wherein the merit of resonance with the cosmos arises. Here, in this chapter, the Nine Passings are again recorded, beginning with the self—does this not invert the proper order?

The methods of cultivation may proceed from within to without, or from without to within. Those who cultivate from within to without perfect the self, and their virtue becomes genuine. Those who proceed from without to inward may place the self last, yet the self comes first.

Careful reflection on the scripture’s intent reveals no discrepancy with the preceding chapter. However, the merit of a single Passing reverberates through the Nine Heavens, and the primordial womb is fully opened—these principles admit of two explanations, hence they are recorded separately.

As the *Scripture of Salvation* states: reciting it once causes all the great sages of the heavens to praise it in unison; after ten recitations, withered bones revive and rise as living beings—this records the merit of ten recitations. Elsewhere it says: reciting it once summons the boundless hosts of the Perfected and Great Spirits of the Eastern Limitless Realm, who descend floating through the void—this records the principle of resonance. The sequence here mirrors that of this scripture; scholars must not cling to one approach alone.

**One Passing: Penetrating the Heavens** opens the primordial womb and its origins—this refers to the beginning of human life. By the **Nine Passings**, the fundamental joints and origins simultaneously generate the gods, thereby expounding the teachings of self-cultivation. The meaning of the **Chapter on Generating the Gods** thus becomes clear.

Before birth, one dwells in darkness, devoid of light, without agency, suspended in obscurity. Though free from the fetters of affliction, even after countless eons, one remains but a wandering spirit, a suffering shade—what benefit is there? Zhuangzi lamented the metal in the crucible, grieving that after becoming human, one merely rots like grass and wood, deeming non-existence more peaceful. Those who fail to awaken seize upon this as justification, and those who speak of longevity dismiss it as an excrescence—truly, they are sinners within the teachings. Such is the fate of those who cultivate imperfectly and perish midway, using this as an excuse—how can this be worthy?

There are those who disdain life, regarding the four great elements as a temporary abode, enduring thirst without drinking, hunger without eating, lacking means to ward off cold or attain satiety. Their bodies wither, their mouths speak of suffering and emptiness, and they sit awaiting death. It is like dismantling a house to live exposed, or taking medicine to induce illness when no sickness exists—how can this accord with human nature? If this were deemed correct, heaven and earth would nearly cease to function.

The Heavenly Worthy and Divine Kings, pitying such inverted views, thus composed the **Chapter on Generating the Gods**, awakening people to the truth that this body is born alongside heaven and earth. If one cultivates according to what is generated and refines what ought to be generated, this is the Dao of long life. Otherwise, Zhuangzi’s lament for the metal in the crucible remains apt. As Shao Kangjie’s poem says: *"To die in vain a thousand times is just as if one had never been born."*

When a person is conceived, essence and blood form the womb, gestating in the mother’s palace for three hundred days before the fetus is complete. At the moment essence and blood coalesce into the womb, a yellow, evolving qi emerges as the origin of life. If this qi flows unimpeded, ascending and descending without losing its measure, the principle of life gradually takes shape. If the womb’s source is obstructed, premature death or stillbirth may occur. Thus, the *Hidden Book of the Great Elixir* states: *"If the Great One congeals, the nine qi stagnate and fail to transform; the Three Ones grieve and cannot gather, allowing the qi of death to enter, preventing completion."*

**Two Passings: Resounding the Earth** unbinds the root of the fetal knot. Heaven is one, earth is two—these are the numbers of heaven and earth. Sound arises and echoes, yang initiates and yin responds. In the second month of human gestation, the fetus begins to take shape, marking the inception of form. Yet birth is the root of death; once the fetal form is established, the qi of death solidifies its root. Thus, those who perish in the womb or die before birth are not uncommon. Hence, the second chapter states: *"Sever the root, seal the gate of death, nurture the infant with brightness and harmony."* Once the fetal root is unbound and the principle of life gradually matures, it is like the Supreme One Emperor Lord’s method of resolving the three barriers and twelve knots with cinnabar talismans inscribed on green bamboo membranes—this is recorded in the *Upper Clarity Cavern Mystery Scripture*.

**Three Passings: Spirit Transforms** refines the Gate of the Hun into immortality. Heaven-one generates water, which in humans becomes essence; heaven-three generates wood, which in humans becomes the hun-soul. At the third Passing, the hun-soul first takes form. The *Scripture of Jade Mushroom Immortals* states: *"In the third month of gestation, yin and yang divide."* Once yin and yang separate, the hun-soul arises on the left and the po-soul on the right—this is an inevitable principle. Those who cultivate must first restrain the hun and control the po. The hun pertains to mercury, the po to lead. Mercury’s nature is volatile; at death, the hun departs first. The *Scripture of Salvation* says: *"The lofty, pure, and numinous spirits sing mournfully in the vast sky"*—lamenting the death of humans.

At conception, once the hun-soul is complete, the physical form is established, entering the Gate of Primordial Simplicity, where yin and yang separate and intermingle. The left is the Gate of the Hun, the right the Door of the Po. Once the hun is refined, the dead may be revived, and the living may attain immortality—hence the term *"extending the heavens"* refers to the qi of enlightened immortality. The character *"refine"* (炼) here denotes the process of silk purification, as used frequently in the scriptures, rather than the character for *"smelting"* (炼). It signifies the primordial simplicity—the fundamental origin of human life, for *"when the root is established, the Dao is born."*

chunks.original_text: 当太素之时，刚柔始分，取其纯素，如缯练之洁，易於成仙矣。 故后章有飘飘练素华，义与此同。 四过天王降仙，魄户闭关。 天四生金，在人为肺，肺所以藏魄。 三过既云魂门，四过云魄户者，盖一身之门户也。 且人之初生，肾为始，脾次之。 脾又生肝，肝方生肺。 肝之与肺，为传导之门户。 且肾为水也，水中有火，升之为气，乘气上升，朝之於心。 心中生液，负阴而下，以归於肾。 若无肝肺为之传导，安得交媾而成龙虎耶。 古仙至人所以炼丹不成，大患金木间隔。 今若使肝能传导其肾气，以朝於心，肺能传导其心液，以至於肾。 时候不差，黄芽乃生，是曰金丹，岂不伟欤。 既云传导，又云魄户闭关，何耶。 此乃始生之户，未能修炼。 恐招死气以伤生气，故以令闭关也。 五过五帝朝真，藏腑清冻。 人生五月，五藏乃分，则脾数始足，见於内者为藏，见於外者为肉。 则五帝自然相朝，青帝护魂，白帝侍魄，赤帝养气，黑帝通血，黄帝中主，万神无越。 六腑者，地二生火，次生小肠，小肠生大肠，大肠生胆，胆生胃，胃生膀胱，兼三焦为六腑也。 呜呼，非彼无我，非我无所取。 则是亦因彼，彼亦因是，生神之妙，岂特不得其朕，可谓自然也。
chunks.translated_text:
At the time of Primordial Simplicity, when hardness and softness first separate, one takes its pure essence—like silk purified to whiteness—thus easily attaining immortality. Hence the later passage speaks of *"the floating, floating refined silk blossom,"* its meaning identical to this. When the Four Celestial Kings descend to bestow immortality, the Door of the Po closes its gate.

The fourth phase generates metal, which in humans becomes the lungs—the repository of the po-soul. The third phase speaks of the Gate of the Hun, while the fourth speaks of the Door of the Po, for these are the gates and doors of the entire body. Moreover, at the beginning of human life, the kidneys form first, followed by the spleen. The spleen then generates the liver, and the liver in turn generates the lungs. Between liver and lungs lie the gates of transmission and conduction.

The kidneys belong to water, yet within water resides fire; when ascended, it becomes qi. Riding this qi upward, it pays homage to the heart. The heart generates fluid, which bears yin downward to return to the kidneys. Without the liver and lungs to transmit and conduct, how could the union be achieved to form the Dragon and Tiger? Thus, the greatest obstacle for ancient immortals and perfected ones in refining the elixir lay in the separation between metal and wood.

Now, if the liver can transmit the kidney’s qi to pay homage to the heart, and the lungs can conduct the heart’s fluid to reach the kidneys—timing without error—then the Yellow Sprout will arise. This is called the Golden Elixir. How magnificent!

Yet if it speaks of transmission and conduction, why also say the Door of the Po closes its gate? This refers to the gate at the beginning of life, before cultivation has begun. Fearing that the qi of death might harm the qi of life, it is thus commanded to close its gate.

In the fifth phase, the Five Emperors pay homage to the perfected, and the viscera become clear and frozen. By the fifth month of human life, the five viscera are fully formed, and the spleen’s count is complete. What appears within is called the *zang*, while what appears without is called flesh. Then the Five Emperors naturally pay homage: the Green Emperor guards the hun, the White Emperor attends the po, the Red Emperor nurtures qi, the Black Emperor circulates blood, and the Yellow Emperor presides at the center—none of the myriad spirits transgress this order.

The six bowels arise as earth generates fire, which then generates the small intestine; the small intestine generates the large intestine; the large intestine generates the gallbladder; the gallbladder generates the stomach; the stomach generates the bladder; together with the Triple Burner, these form the six bowels.

Alas! Without the other, there is no self; without the self, there is nothing to take. Thus, the self depends on the other, and the other depends on the self. The wonder of spirit-generation lies not merely in its absence of traces—it may truly be called natural.

chunks.original_text: 六过魔王伏诺，胃管生津。 五藏皆有津，独左肾为之主。 然胃属土，水得土则止，所以胃管为承津之所。 《仙经存想诀》云：心存胃口有诧女婴儿，裸而无衣，正立胃管，张口承注灵液，仰吸五气，归口咽之，遣入玄女口中是也。 凡人饮食皆聚於胃，暗受亢火磨化。 清者为津，常云雨之润，升於九天，浊者下况，若粪土传泄九地。 聚於口成水，克於肺成唾，克於心成血，克於肾成精，莫非是津也。 如《指玄篇》以心肾为丹元，以肝肾为火侯。 至午静坐幽室，闭目冥心，口含津液，鼻中细细，出息引极，含津以压之，真龙不上升矣。 引息以抽之，真虎不下降矣。 过於黄庭，是为玄珠之常，用之则洗涤胸肠。 故经云：灵镇津液，源张润子。 真人常以此语人云：人身要滋润。 多不晓此，惜哉。 七过星宿朗明，孔窍开聪。 天有七曜，人有七窍，夜行五转者，七曜也。 内行五藏者，七窍也。 人生七月，七星之精，开其七窍，将用视听食息，其七窍则与人均，其聪明则人各异。 然聪明之人，本出於心，心为神属火，火能照物。 七又少阳之数，属金，得金为器，而后能开凿焉。 故上智之人，心有七孔，中人五孔，下者三孔，明达者二孔，寻常一孔，愚痴者无也。 庄子云：岂惟形骸有聋盲哉，夫智亦有之。 倥侗颛蒙，聪明不开，非系於孔窍矣，盖禀赋有厚薄也。 八过幽夜显光，三部八景，整具形神。 人之受生，自一气为祖，以一生三，以三合五，是名八景，三八为二十四神，此阴阳之变也。 若知其变，则宇宙在乎手，造化生乎身。 道家盟威录以三元五德将军为体用，变为二十四阶，应二十四气，正指此也。 所谓变者，莫过於阴阳。 然三五为日月之数，戊己配於坎离。 人禀阴阳之气，三元五运，合於一身。 变而通之，与太极中二十四气自然冥合，故《黄庭》曰：治生之道了不烦，但修洞玄与玉篇，兼及形中八景神，二十四真出自然。 故《素灵经》曰：二十四气混黄杂聚，结气变化，而气中有二十四神，结灵生成，非由胞胎，皆三一帝星之气也。 然则三部八景，整具形神，既曰非由胞胎，为人身者，安得而致之。 能致之者，叉自修行始。 如神仙许长史诀云：以平旦存上景，日中存中景，夜半存下景。 《苞玄玉录》曰：不存二十四气，不知三部八景名字者，不得为太平民，亦不得为后圣臣。 故西城王君、桐栢真人皆行此法，方可得道。 二十四神名数，谨录于下。 上八景，神、发神、皮肤神、目神、项神、神、鼻神、舌神。 中八景：喉神、肺神、心神、肝神、胆神、左肾神、右肾神、脾神。 下八景：胃神、大肠神、小肠神、胴神、胸膈神、两滕神、左阴左阳神、右阴右阳神。 其余形状咒诀，不得尽书之。 曩见鄱阳王侍宸所注，三部八景谓之八卦，甚可笑。 故并书之，以晓后学，免有谬误矣。 九过诸天下临，三关五藏，六腑九宫，金楼玉室十二重门，紫户玉合三万六千关节，根原本始，一时生神。 人未受生，於芒芴之间，是为太易； 变而有气，是为太初； 气变而成形，是为太始； 阴承阳生，气随胎化，是为太素； 灵光入体，与母分形，十月归足，是为太极。 当生之时，万神皆备，从何而致之。 盖生者，天地之大德，天道贵生，因生以致之也。
chunks.translated_text:
The Six Perils’ Demon Kings submit in acquiescence, and the stomach duct generates fluid. The five viscera all possess fluid, but only the left kidney governs it. Now, the stomach belongs to earth, and water is halted by earth—thus the stomach duct becomes the receptacle for fluid. The *Immortal Canon of Visualization Techniques* states: "Visualize at the stomach’s opening a wondrous girl-infant, naked and unclothed, standing upright within the stomach duct. She opens her mouth to receive and channel the numinous liquid, inhaling the five qi upward, drawing them into her mouth to swallow, then sending them into the mouth of the Mysterious Maiden." All that a person eats and drinks gathers in the stomach, silently refined by the scorching fire. The pure becomes fluid, ever moistening like cloud and rain, ascending to the Nine Heavens; the turbid descends as dregs, like excrement and earth, excreted into the Nine Earths. When gathered in the mouth, it becomes water; when refined by the lungs, it becomes spittle; when refined by the heart, it becomes blood; when refined by the kidneys, it becomes essence—none of these are other than fluid. As the *Pointers to the Mysterious* states: the heart and kidneys form the cinnabar origin, while the liver and kidneys serve as the fire’s regulator. At noon, sit in quiet seclusion, close the eyes and still the mind, hold the fluid in the mouth, and draw the breath subtly through the nose to its utmost. Retain the fluid to press it down, and the true dragon will not ascend; draw the breath to withdraw it, and the true tiger will not descend. Passing through the Yellow Court, this becomes the constant of the Mysterious Pearl, which when employed washes and purifies the chest and intestines. Thus the scripture says: "The numinous fluid is locked in place, its source ever-flowing and moistening." The Perfected One often told people: "The human body requires moisture." Yet most do not understand this—what a pity!

The Seven Perils’ stellar lodges shine brightly, and the orifices open to keen perception. Heaven has the seven luminaries, and humans have the seven apertures. Those that traverse the five circuits by night are the seven luminaries; those that course through the five viscera are the seven apertures. In the seventh month of gestation, the essence of the seven stars opens the seven apertures, enabling sight, hearing, eating, and breathing. While the seven apertures are uniform in all people, their acuity varies. Yet acuity originates in the heart, for the heart belongs to spirit and fire, and fire illuminates things. Seven is the number of lesser yang and belongs to metal; only when metal becomes an instrument can it carve and open. Thus, the most intelligent possess seven apertures in the heart, the average have five, the lesser have three, the perceptive have two, the ordinary have one, and the foolish have none. Zhuangzi said: "Is it only the body that may be deaf and blind? Even wisdom may be so." Those who are dull and ignorant, whose acuity remains unopened, are not bound by their apertures—it is rather a matter of innate endowment.

The Eight Perils’ dark night reveals its light, and the Three Regions and Eight Sceneries fully integrate form and spirit. Human life begins with the primal qi as its ancestor. From one comes three, and from three united with five arise the Eight Sceneries. Three eights make the twenty-four spirits—this is the transformation of yin and yang. If one knows this transformation, then the cosmos lies within the palm, and creation arises within the body. The Daoist *Record of the Covenant of Might* takes the Three Origins and Five Virtues Generals as its essence and function, transforming them into twenty-four stages corresponding to the twenty-four qi—this is precisely what is meant. As for transformation, none surpasses that of yin and yang. Now, three and five are the numbers of the sun and moon, with *wu* and *ji* paired with *kan* and *li*. Humans receive the qi of yin and yang, the Three Origins and Five Movements, uniting them within the body. Transforming and harmonizing them, they naturally align with the twenty-four qi within the Supreme Ultimate. Thus the *Yellow Court Canon* says: "The Way of nurturing life is not burdensome—simply cultivate the *Cavernous Mystery* and *Jade Chapters*, along with the Eight Scenery Spirits within the body, and the twenty-four Perfected will emerge naturally." Therefore, the *Plain Questions and Spiritual Pivot* states: "The twenty-four qi intermingle in yellow chaos, congealing into qi and transforming. Within the qi dwell twenty-four spirits, congealing into numen and generating life—not from the womb, but all from the qi of the Three-One Imperial Stars." Now, if the Three Regions and Eight Sceneries fully integrate form and spirit, yet are said not to originate from the womb, how then may one attain them in the human body? Those who attain them must begin with self-cultivation. As the immortal Xu the Grand Master’s instructions say: "At dawn, visualize the Upper Scenery; at noon, the Middle Scenery; at midnight, the Lower Scenery." The *Treasured Jade Record* states: "One who does not visualize the twenty-four qi or know the names of the Three Regions and Eight Sceneries cannot be a citizen of Great Peace, nor a minister of the Later Sage." Thus, the Perfected Lords of West City and the Paulownia-Cypress Immortal both practiced this method to attain the Dao. The names and numbers of the twenty-four spirits are respectfully recorded below.

**Upper Eight Sceneries:**
Spirit of the Fontanel, Spirit of the Hair, Spirit of the Skin, Spirit of the Eyes, Spirit of the Neck, Spirit of the Ears, Spirit of the Nose, Spirit of the Tongue.

**Middle Eight Sceneries:**
Spirit of the Throat, Spirit of the Lungs, Spirit of the Heart, Spirit of the Liver, Spirit of the Gallbladder, Spirit of the Left Kidney, Spirit of the Right Kidney, Spirit of the Spleen.

**Lower Eight Sceneries:**
Spirit of the Stomach, Spirit of the Large Intestine, Spirit of the Small Intestine, Spirit of the Navel, Spirit of the Diaphragm, Spirit of the Knees, Spirit of the Left Yin and Left Yang, Spirit of the Right Yin and Right Yang.

The remaining forms, incantations, and instructions cannot be fully recorded here. I once saw the commentary by Wang Shen of Poyang on the Three Regions and Eight Sceneries, which called them the Eight Trigrams—how laughable! Thus, I have written this out to enlighten later students and prevent such errors.

The Nine Perils’ myriad heavens descend in observation, and the Three Passes, Five Viscera, Six Bowels, Nine Palaces, Golden Towers and Jade Chambers, Twelve Heavy Gates, Purple Portals and Jade Caskets, and thirty-six thousand joints—all their roots and origins simultaneously generate spirit. Before a person receives life, in the boundless void, this is called the Supreme Simplicity. When it transforms into qi, this is called the Supreme Origin. When qi transforms into form, this is called the Supreme Beginning. Yin receives yang and generates life, qi follows the transformation of the embryo—this is called the Supreme Simplicity. When the numinous light enters the body and separates from the mother, after ten months of gestation, this is called the Supreme Ultimate. At the moment of birth, the myriad spirits are all complete—from whence do they come? Life is the great virtue of Heaven and Earth. The Way of Heaven values life, and it is through life that they are attained.

chunks.original_text: 三关者，《黄庭经》以口为天关，手为人关，足为地关。 仙经以泥丸为上关，绛官为中关，下元为下关。 惟正阳真人以夹脊之节有二十四，凡一关有三节焉。 脑之下名曰玉关，其夹脊名日中关，内肾相对名日下关。 又以目为上关，鼻为中关，口为下关。 五藏见上注。 五藏六腑既生神，则大肠为玉堂腑，小肠为元阳腑，左膀为太和腑，右胱为太素腑，胃为中黄腑，胆为太清腑，是名六腑也。 九官者，肾为丹元宫，小肠为朱陵宫，肝为商台宫，胆为天灵宫，脾为黄庭宫，大肠为玄灵宫，肺为尚书宫，膀胱为玉房宫，心为绛霄宫。 《洞真经》云：两眉间入三分为双丹宫，却入一寸为明堂宫，却入三寸为丹田宫，亦名泥丸宫，却入四寸名流珠宫，却入五寸为帝宫。 明堂上一寸名为天庭宫，洞房上一寸名为极真宫，丹田上一寸为玄丹宫，流珠上一寸为太皇官。 金楼则喉咙是也，一名重楼。 中有十二亭长，皆持玉戟以守之，真人在其内，主通上下气者也。 近世苏东坡有云：冻合玉楼寒起粟，盖指此也。 《黄庭经》云：重中楼阙十二环，自高自下皆真人。 玉室者，脑宫之别名也。 《黄庭经》谓之琼室。 十二重门，言喉咙之十二环也。 紫户者，《素灵中篇》云：两眉之上，其裹有紫户。 《洞房内经》云：两关紫户，至於玄精。 紫户之神名平静，字法王。 玉合，则《黄庭》谓之玉堂是也。 三万六千关节，根原本始，一时生神。 已上莫非一身之神也，阳神一万八千为外景，阴神一万八千为内神，合而为三万六千，可谓至贵无伦矣。 人知其神而神，可与造化游於无朕，不知其神而神，则终身役役，不见其成功，可不为大哀哉。 九过为一遍，一遍周竟，三界举名，五帝友别，称为真人。 十遍通气，制御万灵，魔王保举，列上诸天。 百遍通神，坐致自然，太一度符，元君受生。 千遍通灵，坐在立亡，仙童玉女，役使束西。 万遍道备，驰骋龙驾，白日登晨。 言道者莫先於阴阳，言阴阳者叉求於通变。 吾之一身，位乎两问，其生与天地并，其数与阴阳通。 前后相继，高下相续，利故无常，终始不一，相济相生，相制相治，无非一气也。 苟知变通，则造化有可易之理，其於坐在立亡而为过。 当经以九过为一遍，十遍通气，百遍通神，千遍通灵，万变道备，方可登晨。 然诵经之数，叉取於九者。 九为阳极，物极则变。 身有九官，外有九窍，天有九天，下列九垒，丹有九转，法有九成。 七八者，阴阳之推，六九者，阴阳之究，推不变而究则变也。 至於九过，而三关五藏、六腑九官，处处生神，备足於三万六千，此非牵合演成三万六千之数，乃气气通变，自然而然也。 如诵经一过，便见胞原宣通。 通之一字，已见於此，苟不能通之，则此身与块土何异，安得坐在立亡。 是以十遍通气，气结为神，百遍通神，神生则有灵，千遍通灵，灵则变通尽利，鼓舞尽神，方可会道。 所以万遍道备，白日登晨，三界举名，名书上天，信矣。 五帝友别，称为真人。 既为五帝之友，则位与五帝并，何故又称为真人。 盖同门为友，而友别者，又分别，当令入何等地。 如《 黄帝四十四方经》 载：凡读太丹隐书、金华洞房，及雌一宝章者，便得称为三洞法师及元景真人。

The Three Passes: The *Yellow Court Scripture* designates the mouth as the Heavenly Pass, the hands as the Human Pass, and the feet as the Earthly Pass. The immortal scriptures take the Mud-Pill Palace as the Upper Pass, the Crimson Palace as the Middle Pass, and the Lower Cinnabar Field as the Lower Pass. Only the Perfected One of True Yang considers the twenty-four vertebrae of the spine, each pass comprising three joints. Below the brain is called the Jade Pass; the spine itself is called the Middle Pass; and the region opposite the inner kidneys is called the Lower Pass. Alternately, the eyes are taken as the Upper Pass, the nose as the Middle Pass, and the mouth as the Lower Pass.

The five viscera are explained in the annotations above. Once the five viscera and six bowels generate spirit, the large intestine becomes the Jade Hall Bowel, the small intestine the Primordial Yang Bowel, the left bladder the Supreme Harmony Bowel, the right bladder the Supreme Simplicity Bowel, the stomach the Central Yellow Bowel, and the gallbladder the Supreme Clarity Bowel—these are the six bowels.

The Nine Palaces: the kidneys are the Cinnabar Prime Palace; the small intestine, the Vermilion Mound Palace; the liver, the Shang Terrace Palace; the gallbladder, the Heavenly Numinous Palace; the spleen, the Yellow Court Palace; the large intestine, the Mysterious Numinous Palace; the lungs, the Ministerial Palace; the bladder, the Jade Chamber Palace; and the heart, the Crimson Empyrean Palace. The *Cavernous Perfection Scripture* states: three-tenths of an inch between the eyebrows is the Twin Cinnabar Palace; one inch inward is the Hall of Light Palace; three inches inward is the Cinnabar Field Palace, also called the Mud-Pill Palace; four inches inward is the Flowing Pearl Palace; five inches inward is the Imperial Palace. One inch above the Hall of Light is the Heavenly Court Palace; one inch above the Cavernous Chamber is the Ultimate Perfection Palace; one inch above the Cinnabar Field is the Mysterious Cinnabar Palace; one inch above the Flowing Pearl is the Supreme August Palace.

The Golden Tower is the throat, also called the Double Tower. Within it are twelve constables, each wielding a jade halberd to guard it, while the Perfected One resides inside, governing the circulation of qi between above and below. In recent times, Su Dongpo wrote: *"Frost seals the jade tower, cold raises gooseflesh"*—referring precisely to this. The *Yellow Court Scripture* says: *"Within the double tower, twelve rings ascend and descend, all inhabited by Perfected Ones."*

The Jade Chamber is another name for the brain palace. The *Yellow Court Scripture* calls it the Jasper Chamber. The Twelve-Layered Gates refer to the twelve rings of the throat. The Purple Portal, as the *Essential Spirit Middle Scroll* states, lies within the space above the two eyebrows. The *Cavernous Chamber Inner Scripture* says: *"The two passes of the Purple Portal extend to the Mysterious Essence."* The spirit of the Purple Portal is named Tranquil Serenity, styled Dharma King.

The Jade Casket, as the *Yellow Court* calls it, is the Jade Hall. The thirty-six thousand joints—roots, origins, and beginnings—generate spirit all at once. All the above are the spirits of the body: eighteen thousand yang spirits form the outer landscape, and eighteen thousand yin spirits form the inner spirits, together making thirty-six thousand—a truly unparalleled treasure. If one knows the spirit as spirit, one may wander with creation in the formless; if one does not know the spirit as spirit, one remains endlessly toiling, never witnessing accomplishment—is this not a great sorrow?

Nine cycles make one round. When one round is complete, the Three Realms record one’s name, the Five Emperors acknowledge one’s distinction, and one is called a Perfected One. Ten rounds unify qi, enabling mastery over the myriad spirits; demon kings offer protection, and one is listed among the heavens. A hundred rounds unify spirit, allowing one to sit and attain spontaneity; the Supreme Unity grants its talisman, and the Primordial Lord bestows life. A thousand rounds unify numinosity, enabling one to sit in existence or vanish at will; jade lads and maidens serve at one’s command. Ten thousand rounds complete the Way, allowing one to ride the dragon chariot and ascend in broad daylight.

In speaking of the Way, nothing precedes yin and yang; in speaking of yin and yang, one must seek their interpenetration. My body stands between the two poles; its life is coeval with Heaven and Earth, and its number accords with yin and yang. Front and back follow in succession, high and low continue without end; advantage and harm are not constant, beginnings and endings are not uniform. They mutually aid, mutually generate, mutually restrain, and mutually govern—all is but a single qi. If one knows how to interpenetrate, then creation has principles that may be altered, and one may achieve existence or vanishing at will through cycles.

The scripture takes nine cycles as one round: ten rounds unify qi, a hundred rounds unify spirit, a thousand rounds unify numinosity, and ten thousand cycles complete the Way—only then may one ascend in daylight. The number of scripture recitations is based on nine, for nine is the utmost of yang, and when things reach their extreme, they transform. The body has nine palaces, externally nine orifices; Heaven has nine heavens, and below are nine tiers. The elixir has nine revolutions, and the method has nine accomplishments. Seven and eight are the reckonings of yin and yang; six and nine are their investigations. Reckoning does not change, but investigation does. Through nine cycles, the Three Passes, Five Viscera, Six Bowels, and Nine Palaces—everywhere—generate spirit, fulfilling the thirty-six thousand. This is not an arbitrary extension to reach that number, but rather the natural result of qi interpenetrating and transforming of itself.

For example, reciting the scripture once already manifests the free flow of the primordial womb. The word "flow" is evident here: if one cannot achieve flow, how does this body differ from a clod of earth? How could one sit in existence or vanish at will? Thus, ten rounds unify qi, and qi congeals into spirit; a hundred rounds unify spirit, and spirit generates numinosity; a thousand rounds unify numinosity, and numinosity achieves perfect transformation and boundless efficacy, fully animating the spirit—only then may one meet the Way. Therefore, ten thousand rounds complete the Way, enabling ascent in broad daylight, the Three Realms recording one’s name, and one’s name inscribed in the heavens—this is truly so.

The Five Emperors acknowledge one’s distinction, and one is called a Perfected One. If one is a friend of the Five Emperors, one’s rank is equal to theirs—why then is one still called a Perfected One? Because those of the same gate are friends, yet "friendly distinction" further differentiates one’s destined realm. For instance, the *Yellow Emperor’s Forty-Four Methods Scripture* states: those who recite the *Great Elixir Hidden Writ*, the *Golden Flower Cavern Chamber*, and the *Feminine Unity Precious Chapter* are thereby called Masters of the Three Caverns and Perfected Ones of the Primordial Radiance.

The Way of Heaven values life, and it is through life that they are attained.
